choices.text: Malaria
Parvovirus
Rubella
Varicella

questions.text: Which of the following infections can cause fetal hydrops?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parvovirus

  • Parvovirus B19 infects rapidly dividing cells
  • It is cytotoxic for erythroid progenitor cells
  • Parvovirus B19 infections in pregnancy can causes fetal anemia, hydrops and fetal death especially if infection happens within 20 weeks of pregnancy

Ref: Page no 654, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Reassure and advise symptomatic treatment
Prescribe antibiotics
Order Zika virus testing
Initiate antiviral therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester presents with fever, rash, and arthralgia. She recently returned from a trip to a region where Zika virus is endemic. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Order Zika virus testing

 

Explanation: Given her symptoms and travel history, testing for Zika virus is crucial due to the risk of congenital Zika syndrome, which can cause microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Testing is done by detecting Zika virus RNA by PCR in blood or urine. It is vector borne (mosquito).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika virus in pregnancy

 

  • This RNA flavivirus is the first major mosquito-borne teratogen recognized
  • Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito bite, but sexual transmission is possible.
  • Maternal-Fetal Infection:
    • Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults.
    • It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days.
    • The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic.
    • In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures
       
  • Diagnosis and Management.
    • Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission
    • Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months.
    • For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended.
    • For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection.
       
  •  Currently, no specific treatment or vaccine is available for Zika infection, although several vaccines are in development

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26th edition pg 3107

choices.text: Elective cesarean delivery regardless of the presence of lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery with administration of antiviral prophylaxis
Induction of labor at 37 weeks to reduce the risk of neonatal infection

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with primary genital herpes infection. What is the most appropriate management regarding delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor

 

Explanation: If a woman has primary genital herpes before pregnancy or in early pregnancy and has no active lesions at the time of labor, vaginal delivery is usually safe. However, if she has active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms at the onset of labor, a cesarean delivery is recommended to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If there is active genital herpes at term, cesarean section has to be done

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Consider termination of pregnancy
Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
IV Acyclovir
Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG)

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1L1 teacher presents at 22 weeks with fever and rash since 2 days. She gives history of contact with a child in her class who had chicken pox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration

Chickenpox in Pregnancy

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: HIV
Genital herpes
Hepatitis B
CMV

questions.text: All are indications of a vaginal delivery except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genital herpes

  • Genital herpes is a contra-indication to vaginal delivery because of the risk of transmission to the fetus. Cesarean section is preferred
  • In all the rest, vaginal delivery is not contra-indicated

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Continue the pregnancy for at least one week
Give varicella zoster vaccine to the neonate soon after birth
Give VZIG to the neonate soon after birth
Induce labor immediately

questions.text: A woman develops chickenpox at 39 weeks. She has a single fetus in the cephalic presentation. She has no other pregnancy complications.  What is the best method to prevent neonatal infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Continue the pregnancy for at least one week 

  • If delivery can be postponed for at least 7 days, the mother will develop antibodies and there will be transplacental transfer of antibodies to the neonate. The neonate will have passive immunity and will not develop the infection. Therefore, the best method to prevent neonatal infection is to continue the pregnancy for at least one week after the mother develops the rash. If delivery occurs within one week, the baby should be given VZIG soon after birth.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: Both mother and baby are safe
Give antiviral treatment to mother before delivery
Give antiviral treatment to baby
Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady acquires chickenpox 3 days prior to delivery. She delivers by normal vaginal route. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. ‘D’ Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome

  • This patient has developed chickenpox 3 days prior to delivery. So, antibodies are not formed in mother (which take at least 5 days’ time to develop). Hence, fetus is not protected.
  • Delivery during the viremic period can cause serious complications to mother and neonatal varicella syndrome which is of very high incidence in exposed neonates
  • In this case, varicella immunoglobulin should be given to neonate.

choices.text: Check for Varicella zoster IgG and if negative, give Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin
Give Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin
Review only if there is a fever with rash
Urgent ultrasound to look for evidence of fetal infection.

questions.text: A 22-year primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD at 18 weeks. She is very worried as she has been in contact with her 7year od nephew who had chicken pox. The contact was 4 days prior. On enquiry, she says she has never had chicken pox earlier. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Check for Varicella zoster IgG and if negative, give Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin

 

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: Fetal cell-mediated and humoral immunity begin to develop at 9-14 weeks.
The primary fetal response to infection is IgG.
Passive immunity is provided by IgG transferred across the placenta.
By 26 weeks, the fetal concentrations of IgG are equivalent to the mother.

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding fetal immunity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The primary fetal response to infection is IgG.

Fetal and Neonatal Immunology

  • Fetal cell-mediated and humoral immunity begin to develop at 9-14 weeks.
  • The primary fetal response to infection is IgM.
  • Passive immunity is provided by IgG transferred across the placenta
  • By 16 weeks, this transfer begins to rise rapidly and by 26 weeks, the fetal concentrations of IgG are equivalent to those of the mother
  • After birth, breastfeeding is protective against some infections

Ref: Page no 1210, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal abnormalities associated with CMV can be seen on sonography.
CMV is the most common perinatal infection in the developed world.
Infection can occur trans-placentally, at delivery or during breastfeeding.
Routine prenatal screening of CMV is recommended.

questions.text: Which is not true about CMV infection in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Routine prenatal screening of CMV is recommended.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in pregnancy

  • It is a DNA Herpes virus.
  • Most common perinatal infection in the developed world
  • Virus is found in all body fluids; and person to person transmission via contact with saliva, semen, urine, blood and nasopharyngeal and cervical secretions can occur
  • Routes of perinatal infections
    • Transplacental
    • During delivery
    • Breastfeeding
  • Mostly asymptomatic; 10-15% have fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and Poly arthropathy.

 

  • Transmission rates:
    • 30% 1st trimester
    • 40% 2nd trimester
    • > 50% 3rd trimester (maximum in the 3rd trimester)

 

  • Fetal Infection: Congenital CMV infection is characterized by
    • Fetal growth restriction
    • Microcephaly
    • Periventricular calcification (Characteristic)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Mental and motor retardation
    • Sensorineural deficits
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Hemolytic anemia; Jaundice
    • Thrombocytic purpura

 

  • Late onset sequelae includes:
    • Hearing loss
    • Neurological deficits
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Psychomotor retardation
    • Learning disabilities

 

  • Prenatal Diagnosis:
    • Routine screening for CMV is currently NOT recommended.
    • Test for CMV if symptomatic mother OR if abnormal sonographic findings suggestive of CMV
      • Test: CMV IgM (IgG positivity is not significant as it may be there because of earlier illness)
      • CMV nucleic acid amplification (NAAT) of amniotic fluid: Gold standard for diagnosis of fetal infection)
    • Management: symptomatic; no proven treatment; No vaccine

 

 

Ref: Page no 1210-1212; William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Cytomegalovirus
Influenza vaccine
Paramyxovirus
Rubella

questions.text: A 24 y Primigravida presents at 20 weeks for her routine ultrasound. On sonography, the fetus is noted to have periventricular calcifications as shown in the image. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Cytomegalovirus

Cytomegalovirus (fetal infection) presents as:

  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Microcephaly
  • Intracranial calcifications
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Mental and motor retardation
  • Sensorineural deficits
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Hemolytic anemia; Jaundice
  • Thrombocytic purpura

Influenza: No firm evidence links congenital malformations and influenza A virus though there is increased risk of preterm, still births and a higher abortion rate.

Paramyxovirus: Infection in pregnancy is not associated with congenital infection and fetal infection is rare.

 

Rubella: Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Maximum risk if infection is in the 1s trimester

 

  • Cardiac septal defects
  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Microcephaly
  • Cataract
  • Microphthalmia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

 

Ref: Page no 1214-1215, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Induction of labor
Oral acyclovir, antipyretics and hydration
USG to rule out congenital varicella infection
Emergency LSCS

questions.text: A 24-year lady at 38 weeks presents with fever and rash suggestive of varicella zoster infection. There are no other high-risk factors. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral acyclovir, antipyretics and hydration

Chickenpox in Pregnancy: if a pregnant woman develops chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

choices.text: Chloroquine
Mefloquine
Primaquine
Quinine

questions.text: A woman who is 18 weeks pregnant attends the antenatal clinic with fever, chills and malaise. She has just returned from working in East Africa. A peripheral blood film is examined, and a diagnosis of malaria is made. The organism identified is Plasmodium vivax. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chloroquine

  • Treat malaria in pregnancy as an emergency.
  • Intravenous artesunate is the treatment of choice for severe falciparum malaria.
  • Use intravenous quinine if artesunate is not available.
  • Use quinine and clindamycin to treat uncomplicated P. falciparum (or mixed, such as P. falciparum and P. vivax).
  • Use chloroquine to treat P. vivax, P. ovale or P. malariae.
  • Primaquine should not be used in pregnancy. (It can cause hemolysis in the fetus)
  • Do not persist with oral therapy if vomiting is persistent.
  • Treat the fever with antipyretics.
  • Screen women with malaria for anaemia and treat appropriately.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg_54b.pdf

choices.text: 1%
3%
5%
10%

questions.text: With the use of anti-retroviral therapy and scheduled cesarean delivery, the perinatal transmission rate of HIV has reduced from 30% to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1%

  • With the use of anti-retroviral therapy and scheduled cesarean delivery, the perinatal transmission rate of HIV has reduced from 30% to < 1%

choices.text: Congenital rubella syndrome-if mother gets infected before 16 weeks
Congenital varicella syndrome-maternal infection between 13-20 weeks
Congenital toxoplasma – Periventricular calcification
Congenital parvovirus-hydrops fetalis

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not correctly paired?
questions.solution:
Ans. ‘C’ Congenital toxoplasmosis-periventricular calcification

 

  • Toxoplasmosis cause hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcification while CMV causes microcephaly and periventricular calcifications.
  • Risk of congenital rubella syndrome is highest in first 16 weeks and includes the triad of cataract, CVS anomalies specially PDA and SNHL. (Greggs triad)
  • PARVOVIRUS B19 causes fetal anemia and causes hydrops fetalis

choices.text: MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine
Influenza vaccine
Varicella vaccine
HPV (human papillomavirus) vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommended vaccine for all pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Influenza vaccine

 

Explanation: The influenza vaccine is recommended for all pregnant women to protect both the mother and the fetus, as pregnant women are at higher risk of complications from influenza.

 

 Other Options:

 

  • Option A and C: MMR and varicella vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their live attenuated nature.
  • Option D: HPV vaccine is also contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaccines given in pregnancy
    • TT, Td or Tdap
      • Td has replaced TT (as per MOHFW)
      • 1st dose: early in pregnancy
      • 2nd dose: After 4 weeks
      • Booster:  if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years
      • Tdap: One dose of Td replaced with Tdap preferably given between 27-36 weeks of gestation (ACOG Committee 2017)
         
    • Influenza (inactivated): As per ACOG, seasonal administration is recommended
       
  • Also remember:
    • All live vaccines are c/I in pregnancy except yellow fever vaccine
    • All covid vaccines can be given in pregnancy
    • Tell patient not to conceive for 1 month after live vaccine has been taken
    • Rabies vaccine is safe (post exposure prophylaxis)
    • All vaccines can be given in lactation
    • Small pox vaccine only known vaccine to cause fetal harm

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 1214

choices.text: Observation and repeat urine culture in the third trimester
Immediate initiation of antibiotic therapy
Administration of intramuscular immunoglobulin
Urology referral for cystoscopy

questions.text: A pregnant woman tests positive for asymptomatic bacteriuria. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Immediate initiation of antibiotic therapy

 

Explanation: Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is treated with antibiotics to prevent the risk of ascending infection and pyelonephritis, which can lead to adverse pregnancy outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asymptomatic bacteruria has to be treated in pregnancy  as if not treated, approximately 25 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
